partial_orders.reason: Both edits perform an identical textual substitution pattern: changing 'events.parallel_quitting' to 'events.quitting' in the same syntactic context (event handler registration lines). This represents a bulk refactoring operation where the same API change is being applied uniformly across multiple classes. Both changed lines target the same type of syntactic construct (event subscription statements) and apply the exact same before→after pattern. This is clearly part of a single, contiguous refactor to rename an event from 'parallel_quitting' to 'quitting' throughout the codebase.

This represents a bulk refactoring operation where the same API change is being applied uniformly across multiple classes. Both changed lines target the same type of syntactic construct (event subscription statements) and apply the exact same before→after pattern. This is clearly part of a single, contiguous refactor to rename an event from 'parallel_quitting' to 'quitting' throughout the codebase.

Both edits reference the exact same symbol 'events.quitting' in their changed lines. Edit 0 changes from 'events.parallel_quitting' to 'events.quitting' in a subscription context, while Edit 1 modifies the firing of 'events.quitting' by adding a 'reverse=True' parameter. These edits appear to be part of a coordinated refactoring where the event system is being modified - changing which event is subscribed to and how that same event is fired. The changes reference the same symbol and would naturally occur together as part of a single micro-task to update the event handling system.

These edits involve moving identical documentation text from one class docstring to another. Edit 0 adds the text 'If reverse is True, then the handlers will run in the reverse order that they were inserted' to the EventHook class docstring, while Edit 1 removes the exact same text from the ParallelEventHook class docstring. This appears to be a cut-and-paste move operation where the documentation is being relocated from the child class to the parent class. For a proper cut-and-paste move, the removal must occur before the addition to avoid having duplicate text temporarily present in the codebase.

Edit 0 adds documentation about a 'reverse' parameter to the EventHook class docstring, while Edit 1 adds the actual 'reverse' parameter to the fire() method signature and implements its functionality. The documentation in Edit 0 directly describes the behavior implemented in Edit 1 - they reference the exact same parameter and functionality. This creates a bi-directional relationship where either edit naturally prompts the other as the next step: adding the parameter implementation prompts updating the documentation, or adding the documentation prompts implementing the described functionality.

Edit 0 adds a 'reverse' parameter to the fire() method signature in the EventHook class. Edit 1 updates a call to events.quitting.fire() to pass reverse=True. These edits reference the exact same symbol - the fire() method being called on events.quitting (which is an EventHook instance). After adding the parameter in edit 0, the call site in edit 1 becomes the immediate next step to utilize the new parameter. This is a classic signature-caller relationship where both changed lines reference the same method symbol.
